title: Why is it so easy for some people to believe in pseudoscience? - Quora

response.answer_text: Someday you wake up and realize wearing your lucky Spaceman Spiff underwear isn't enough to guarantee a good day. But, what can you do? People hold faith in or accept as fact what seems to support their present comfort, whether we're talking about homeostasis or social standing, for so long as it seems plausible enough or necessary to do so.  For some, it's a choice; for most, it's training; and for many, they've just never considered another way.  It's only when uncomfortable and confronted with some sense of implausibility or unreliability in their personal schema for reality (and the belief that they won't be burned at the stake for defying the gods or contradicting the natural order) that they get curious enough to question. However, as often as not or more so, people don't wake up one day with newfound objective capacities for dispassionately examining evidence or even a clearer understanding of the question. So, they just think what they've learned to think, do what they've always done, and hope for better results in the new day. After all, the world is great, the sky endless, the gods' ways mysterious, and any apparent cruelty is probably because of our lack of faith or to chasten our tolerance for our wicked neighbor's godless ways. In troubled times, one still hopes to wear the most comfortable underwear one can find.  In a crisis, we go back to the last thing that seemed plausible and supportive for hope and moral strength in distress. That's part of the human emotional architecture. Sorry. You've probably heard that there are no atheists in foxholes, and it certainly can be challenging to keep a level head when deranged lunatics suddenly appear, trying to take your head off while shouting their plan to be intolerant of your wicked, godless ways - whatever that's supposed to mean. You might've thought you were there to aid them with the mystery behind their failing crops, but concern can go right out the window when fanatics and zealots with weapons show up. Two points of advise for dealing with situations like these: Be careful how you tell local tribesmen that bodies they've buried in their fields have enriched the soil - though not because any sacrificial value to their gods. They might take away the wrong message.Don't be too quick to declare yourself high priest of whichever deity you promised obedience in exchange for surviving the last battle. It's... Well, it's just possible you didn't survive as a result of the divine intervention of Horus (or any gods named since). Have you heard of Stockholm Syndrome?
